climbs.name: Where Men Are Men and Sheep Are Nervous
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Tim Toula. April 2004

content.description: Starts on top of a ledge, just left of cold shuts for Arachnicopia. Big ledge in the middle of the route presents a possible deck if you blow the crux move at the last two bolts. Go right for an easy 5.9 flake here, or straight up bolt line for .10ish move above last bolt.
content.location: Middle of the face above the south fence of the corral.

content.description:
2 bolts, cool short fun route. Shares open cold shuts eith Arachnicopia. Saw a snake chillin among the rocks and cow pies below the route.

Please comment if you know the name/FA on this
content.protection: 2 bolts to open cold shuts. Yep, it's pretty short
content.location: rightmost of three short bolted routes at ground level behind the south end of the corral

content.description:
Any info on this would be helpful. Please comment if you know anything.

Good but short route, we weren't sure what it was but it looked easy.
content.location: Left of Arachnicopia, this is the furthest left of the 3 short bolted routes on ground level immediately behind the south end of the corral.

content.description: A few meters right of the Butt Crack Roof, start up a short, dirty gully to get onto the good rock and clip the first bolt. Â 5.6 slab climbing with a crux located in the first 2-3 clips trends to easier ground above and a nice flat party ledge with the bolted anchor in the back.
content.protection: bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Located to the right of Butt Crack Roof.

content.description: Arete above and left of the south end of the corral. Garrett's book says bolted but suggests small cams and nuts as well
content.protection: Bolts, suggested small cams and nuts
content.location: Arete facing southeast just left and up on the far left of the ledge that has Bodagette and Where Men Are Men

content.description: North facing roof route with a name that is very fitting
content.location: Furthest south of the central area. If you can't see it walk to the corral and look southwest for the elevated cheeks

climbs.name: Bodaggette
climbs.fa: Jason Stevens and Jared Nielsen, Fall 2003

content.description: The route starts with a sidepull and a high step and gets right into the business with awkward finger locks and jams before moving onto easier terrain. The final two bolts guard a short steep section.
content.protection: A few small pieces of gear could be placed but the route is fully protected with bolts. Very mild runouts on the easy middle section. Two chain anchor on top.
content.location: Look for a southern facing spur of rock just above the corrals. Highly visible from the parking lot, 30 feet left of the fence edge.

content.description: Large white roof next to the corral and below some other central corral area routes. Pull the roof for some good jugs, easy to chicken out but do the roof, you'll be happy you did! Shares anchor with route to its right
content.location: Center of 3 bolted lines next to the south end of the corral on the short wall.  Look for the large white section of rock below the roof.
